study_goal: To update the current best evidence on the effectiveness and safety of cupping therapy in pain management.
results_summary: Cupping therapy alone or combined with other therapies showed benefits in relieving pain, improving quality of life, and increasing cure rates, though the evidence quality was low. Adverse events in cupping groups were reported to be lower than in control groups, but the evidence strength was limited by study heterogeneity and methodological quality.
population_specificity: Patients with pain conditions (5,720 participants across 72 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different control interventions against cupping therapy for chronic nonspecific low back pain (CLBP) to identify the most suitable control for future RCTs.
results_summary: Cupping therapy showed similar efficacy to minimum negative pressure cupping therapy (MNPCT) and air circulating cupping therapy (ACCT), but was significantly more effective than D-ibuprofen, paracetamol, and usual care in reducing pain intensity. The SUCRA ranking indicated cupping therapy as the most effective intervention among those studied.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic nonspecific low back pain (CLBP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether moving cupping therapy (MCT) combined with conventional physiotherapy improves pain and functionality in patients with Rotator Cuff Injuries (RCI).
results_summary: The study found that MCT combined with conventional physiotherapy significantly improved pain, range of motion, and functionality in RCI patients compared to conventional physiotherapy alone. However, emotional well-being improvements were significantly better in the control group.
population_specificity: 30 women aged 25-65 diagnosed with RCI at a physical therapy clinic in Istanbul.
effective_dosage: MCT was administered for 10 minutes, 2 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of cupping therapy as a non-pharmacological treatment for knee osteoarthritis pain.
results_summary: The study found that cupping therapy significantly reduced pain (NPRS score decreased from 8 to 2), improved stiffness and functional ability (WOMAC score decreased from 50 to 25), and enhanced quality of life (SF-36 score improved from 35 to 75) in a patient with knee osteoarthritis.
population_specificity: A 57-year-old female with a 3-year history of right knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neurological complications associated with cupping therapy by reviewing case reports and case studies.
results_summary: The study found that cupping therapy, though rare, can lead to severe neurological complications such as subdural hemorrhage, with most cases involving combined traditional therapies. Most patients recovered with treatment, but the risks highlight the need for practitioner awareness and precautions.
population_specificity: Patients who experienced neurological complications following cupping therapy (14 cases from 12 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the efficacy and safety of Cupping Therapy (CT) on acupoint CV8 Shenque as a treatment for urticaria.
results_summary: CT on CV8 Shenque significantly improved effective rate (ER), symptom scores (SS), and quality of life (QoL) compared to other treatments, though the overall quality and quantity of included RCTs were not satisfactory.
population_specificity: 409 patients with urticaria across six RCTs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the multitarget mechanisms of oxhorn cupping therapy (OHCT) in treating rheumatoid arthritis through proteomic analysis.
results_summary: The study found that OHCT-treated rheumatoid arthritis patients had exosomes in their body fluid, with 300 differentially expressed proteins (DEPs) identified post-treatment. OHCT appeared to influence multiple signaling pathways and protein targets, including slight decreases in serum levels of CDK1, ITGA5, ITGB5, and CD44.
population_specificity: Thirty rheumatoid arthritis patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantitatively assess the effects of cupping therapy at different negative pressures on local tissue microenvironments, including blood circulation, lymphatic drainage, and potential anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: Low-pressure cupping (-20 kPa) improved blood circulation and lymphatic drainage, while high-pressure cupping (-30 kPa) caused capillary rupture and tissue damage. The study also suggested potential benefits for sepsis outcomes in mice due to anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Mice (animal study)
study_duration: Effects observed within two hours post-intervention

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute effect of different types of cupping therapy (static, dynamic, and sham) on ankle dorsiflexion range of motion (ROM).
results_summary: The study found an overall increase in ankle ROM post-intervention, with no significant differences between cupping therapy groups. However, dynamic cupping resulted in a clinically meaningful change in ROM exceeding the minimal detectable change.
population_specificity: Generally healthy adults (mean age 22.1 ± 4.52 years) with baseline ankle ROM of 34.68 ± 4.22°.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of infectious endocarditis caused by unsanitary cupping therapy in a patient with untreated atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The study found that unsanitary cupping therapy led to a skin infection, which subsequently caused infectious endocarditis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, and cerebral infarction in the patient.
population_specificity: A 23-year-old man with untreated atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of cupping therapy's application in women's health and understand its importance.
results_summary: The study highlights cupping therapy's growing global attention for health promotion and treatment, particularly in women's health, but does not provide specific efficacy results.
population_specificity: Women (general focus, no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether multiple cups of negative pressure cupping therapy induce interactions in hemodynamic responses between different areas using wavelet phase coherence analysis of NIRS signals.
results_summary: The study found higher oxyhemoglobin and deoxyhemoglobin coherence between two inside-cup areas at -75 mmHg compared to -300 mmHg, suggesting that lower negative pressure may enhance hemodynamic interactions. These effects were observed in both metabolic and neurogenic controls.
population_specificity: 12 healthy adults
effective_dosage: Three levels of negative pressure (-75, -225, and -300 mmHg) applied to the gastrocnemius

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of moving cupping therapy combined with acupoint bloodletting in treating plaque psoriasis.
results_summary: The study found that the combination therapy significantly improved skin lesions, reduced PASI and BSA scores, and enhanced quality of life, with no relapse observed during a 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: A 35-year-old male with a 20-year history of plaque psoriasis.
effective_dosage: Moving cupping therapy combined with acupoint bloodletting once every other day, three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of cupping therapy in treating migraine headache disorder, comparing different cupping techniques and adjunctive treatments.
results_summary: Cupping therapy significantly improved treatment success and reduced pain intensity, particularly with wet cupping, but did not enhance overall quality of life. Adverse events were fewer with cupping therapy compared to controls.
population_specificity: 1,446 participants with migraine headaches (797 received cupping therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the time response differences of cupping therapy between pre- and post-fatigue intervention timings and its effects on muscle fatigue recovery using sEMG nonlinear analysis.
results_summary: Post-condition cupping therapy showed significant delayed effects in alleviating muscle fatigue, particularly 3 hours after intervention, while pre-condition therapy maintained muscles in a non-fatigued state but did not significantly enhance muscle performance. No significant differences were found between groups except at the 3-hour post-intervention mark.
population_specificity: 26 healthy volunteers with non-dominant upper extremity muscle fatigue induced by repeated biceps curls.
effective_dosage: -300 mmHg pressure for 5 minutes using a 45 mm-diameter cup.
study_duration: Single session with follow-up measurements at baseline, immediately post-intervention, 3 hours, and 6 hours post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of wet-cupping therapy (WCT) on repeated sprint ability, wellness, and exertion in young active males.
results_summary: WCT moderately enhanced repeated sprint ability (higher maximum, mean, and minimum power) and improved perceived sleep, stress, and exertion compared to the control session.
population_specificity: 49 active adult males (age 28 ± 5 years, BMI 25.4 ± 1.8 kg/m²).
study_duration: WCT was performed 24 hours before the testing session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the potential life-threatening infectious complications of cupping therapy, particularly in patients with compromised skin barriers.
results_summary: The study reported a case of intracranial mycotic aneurysm rupture following cupping therapy, leading to severe complications requiring surgical intervention and rehabilitation. It underscores the risks of infection when proper preventive measures are not followed.
population_specificity: A 25-year-old male with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-asthmatic effects of wet cupping therapy (WCT) in patients with mild to moderate asthma.
results_summary: WCT significantly increased the mean total treatment score (MTTS) in asthma patients by the eighth week post-intervention, with higher satisfaction scores compared to the control group. The intervention group showed significant improvement in asthma symptoms as early as the first week.
population_specificity: 103 asthma patients (82 completed the study) with mild to moderate asthma, referred to Loghman Hakim Hospital, Tehran, Iran.
effective_dosage: One session of WCT performed on one of the 17th, 19th, or 21st days of the lunar month.
study_duration: 8 weeks (follow-up assessments at weeks 1, 2, 4, 6, and 8 post-intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of cupping therapy on a patient with long-standing Meniere's disease.
results_summary: Over two years of monthly cupping therapy sessions, the patient reported a decrease in symptom intensity and frequency until symptoms disappeared. The study suggests cupping therapy may be beneficial for Meniere's disease.
population_specificity: A 54-year-old patient with long-standing Meniere's disease.

study_goal: To investigate the profile, training, clinical practice, and scientific updates of Brazilian Physical Therapists who use cupping therapy for musculoskeletal disorders.
results_summary: Cupping therapy is widely adopted by young, female, recently graduated Physical Therapists, primarily due to patient demand. It is often used alongside other manual techniques, but its use lacks strong scientific evidence.
population_specificity: Brazilian Physical Therapists using cupping therapy (n=646).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether cupping therapy improves muscle quality and how the interaction between duration and negative pressure affects muscle quality.
results_summary: The study found that cupping therapy significantly increased contrast texture and decreased correlation texture in the superficial layer of the triceps, with varying effects based on pressure and duration. Homogeneity among soft tissues of the treated muscle decreased after cupping therapy.
population_specificity: 12 participants
effective_dosage: Cupping pressures at -225 and -300 mmHg for durations of 5 and 10 minutes

study_goal: To determine the optimal duration of thumb cupping therapy for frozen shoulder using thermal metabolic imaging and assess clinical efficacy and safety.
results_summary: Groups receiving 10 and 15 minutes of cupping showed higher clinical efficacy and lower pain scores than the 5-minute group, with the 10-minute group demonstrating the best balance of efficacy and safety. The 15-minute group had the highest adverse reaction incidence, while the 10-minute group showed the greatest temperature improvement efficiency.
population_specificity: 120 patients with frozen shoulder.
effective_dosage: 5, 10, or 15 minutes of thumb cupping therapy.
study_duration: Treatment duration varied by group (5, 10, or 15 minutes per session).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of laser auriculotherapy combined with cupping therapy on chronic spinal pain.
results_summary: The experimental group showed significant reductions in pain intensity and increased pain thresholds compared to the control group, with sustained effects at follow-up. The control group experienced a reduction in nociceptive threshold but no significant pain relief.
population_specificity: 50 individuals with chronic spinal pain (cervical, thoracic, and lumbar regions).
effective_dosage: 10 sessions of auriculotherapy with laser and cupping therapy (frequency not specified).
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but follow-up was 15 days post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore changes in pain and function following combined local static and distal dynamic myofascial dry cupping treatments in patients with chronic low back pain.
results_summary: The study found that combined cupping therapy reduced pain, pain sensitivity, and perceived disability while improving hamstring muscle extensibility in all three participants. These results suggest potential benefits but require further investigation in larger controlled trials.
population_specificity: Three adults with chronic low back pain from the general population.
effective_dosage: Three ten-minute treatment sessions, 48 hours apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of wet-cupping therapy on reducing both physiological and mental pain in patients with migraine.
results_summary: The study found that wet-cupping therapy significantly reduced both physiological and mental pain severity in migraine patients, with effects observed immediately (10 minutes) and sustained at 1-month follow-up. The therapy showed stronger effects on physiological pain compared to mental pain.
population_specificity: 72 patients with migraine.
study_duration: Follow-up at 10 minutes and 1 month post-therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effects and central mechanism of Yang's pricking-cupping therapy on eczema-induced pruritus using rs-fMRI.
results_summary: Yang's pricking-cupping therapy significantly reduced pruritus severity, eczema symptoms, and improved quality of life and sleep, while also normalizing abnormal brain activity in regions related to pruritus and emotional regulation.
population_specificity: 50 patients with eczema-induced pruritus (observation group) and 50 healthy subjects (control group).
effective_dosage: Once a week at specific acupoints (GV 14, LI 11, SP 10, SP 6).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of cupping therapy on low back pain (LBP), examining its impact based on treatment durations, cupping types, treatment locations, and LBP classifications.
results_summary: High- to moderate-quality evidence indicates that cupping significantly improves pain and disability, with superior and sustained effects compared to medication and usual care. However, effectiveness varied by treatment duration, cupping type, and location, with notable heterogeneity among studies.
population_specificity: Adults with low back pain (excluding acute cases), across all ethnicities.
study_duration: Varied, with follow-ups ranging from immediate post-intervention to 3-6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of cupping therapy versus the Graston technique in reducing pain and improving function in individuals with medial tibial stress syndrome (MTSS).
results_summary: Cupping therapy showed significant pain reduction (p-value 0.01) and improved functional outcomes compared to the Graston technique after three weeks of treatment. The study concluded that cupping therapy might be more effective than the Graston technique for MTSS.
population_specificity: 46 participants with medial tibial stress syndrome (MTSS) caused by sports or strenuous activities.
effective_dosage: Four weekly sessions (frequency not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of cupping therapy in treating substance use disorder and managing withdrawal symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that cupping therapy was ineffective in treating substance use disorder or managing withdrawal symptoms, as the patient's condition did not improve with this intervention. Standard treatment was required to alleviate withdrawal symptoms.
population_specificity: A patient addicted to alprazolam, codeine, and tobacco.

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of cupping therapy on pain, quality of life, sleep disorders, and disease impact in subjects with fibromyalgia.
results_summary: Cupping therapy showed large effect sizes for pain intensity, moderate for quality of life, and low for fibromyalgia impact and sleep disorders, but the certainty of evidence was low for most outcomes.
population_specificity: Adults with fibromyalgia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of Cupping Therapy (CT) at CV8 Shenque for treating urticaria through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The study will analyze existing randomized controlled trials to assess symptom scores, quality of life, effective rate, and adverse events, but specific results are not yet provided as it is a protocol for future analysis.
population_specificity: Urticaria patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize existing evidence on cupping therapy's efficacy for pain-related outcomes and assess the quality of that evidence.
results_summary: The study found that cupping therapy may be effective for managing chronic pain, knee osteoarthritis, low back pain, neck pain, chronic back pain, and herpes zoster, but the evidence quality ranged from very low to moderate. No high-quality evidence was identified.
population_specificity: Patients with pain-related conditions (neck pain, low back pain, chronic back pain, knee osteoarthritis, herpes zoster).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different pressures and durations of cupping therapy affect the spatial hemodynamic response in the biceps muscle.
results_summary: The study found a significant three-way interaction between location, pressure, and duration on oxyhemoglobin, deoxy-hemoglobin, and blood volume. A significant increase in oxyhemoglobin, blood volume, and oxygenation was observed outside the cupping area compared to pre-cupping.
population_specificity: 18 participants (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: Pressures of -225 and -300 mmHg, durations of 5 and 10 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate public attitudes toward the effectiveness, safety, and expected standards of practicing wet cupping in Saudi Arabia.
results_summary: Most participants believed wet cupping is beneficial and safe but not suitable for all diseases or individuals. They preferred it performed at specialized centers by qualified practitioners using sterile instruments.
population_specificity: Saudi adults (mean age 30.43 ± 11.4 years; 42.1% male, 57.9% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of wet cupping therapy (WCT) as a complementary treatment for fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS).
results_summary: The study found that WCT significantly reduced fibromyalgia impact (FIQ) and pain (VAS) scores while improving quality of life (QoL) compared to the control group, with all changes being statistically significant (p < 0.001).
population_specificity: 120 participants (107 female, 13 male) aged 18-65 diagnosed with FMS.
effective_dosage: 3 sessions of WCT, administered once a month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of cupping therapy on spatial hemodynamic responses and the correlation between oxyhemoglobin and deoxy-hemoglobin using multi-channel NIRS signals.
results_summary: The study found that the maximum cross-correlation function (CCF) values of oxyhemoglobin were significantly higher than those of deoxy-hemoglobin, and there was a correlation between deoxy-hemoglobin levels and longer duration/larger magnitude of negative pressure.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract does not mention demographic details).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical efficacy of fire needling combined with cupping therapy versus western medication for treating acute-stage herpes zoster, and to assess their effects on Th17 and Treg cells and inflammatory factors (IL-10 and IL-17).
results_summary: The combined therapy group showed lower symptom scores, reduced pain, shorter blister/scabbing times, and lower postherpetic neuralgia incidence compared to the western medication group. It also modulated immune balance by reducing Th17/Treg ratio and inflammatory cytokine levels.
population_specificity: 80 patients with acute-stage herpes zoster.
effective_dosage: Fire needling plus cupping once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects and safety of cupping therapy on obesity through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found that cupping therapy improved body weight, BMI, hip circumference, and waist circumference, but showed no significant changes in waist-hip ratio or body fat percentage. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the knowledge, practice, and attitude toward cupping therapy among physicians in Sheikh Khalifa Medical City.
results_summary: The study found that 67.5% of physicians had adequate knowledge of cupping therapy, 66.9% showed a positive attitude, and 31.2% reported good practice. Over 80% of physicians agreed that cupping therapy could treat conditions like low back pain, joint discomfort, headache, migraine, and anxiety.
population_specificity: Physicians at Sheikh Khalifa Medical City (SKMC) in the United Arab Emirates.
study_duration: Survey conducted from September 2020 to March 2021 (no intervention duration specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Al-hijamah (wet cupping therapy) as a potential adjuvant treatment for viral hepatitis (B and C) and HCC by assessing its ability to reduce viral load, enhance antiviral immunity, and repair tissue damage.
results_summary: The study suggests Al-hijamah effectively clears pathological substances (e.g., excess ferritin, free radicals) and enhances antioxidant power and antiviral immunity (e.g., increased CD4/CD8 counts). It also proposes benefits for HCC by excreting malignancy-favoring substances and immune potentiation.
population_specificity: Patients with viral hepatitis (B and C) and HCC, with prior reference to thalassemic children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether wet cupping therapy (WCT) could effectively treat an acute hand abscess when combined with conventional drug therapy.
results_summary: The study found that wet cupping therapy, combined with conventional drug therapy, successfully cured the hand abscess within a week, resolving both the abscess and surrounding edema.
population_specificity: A 43-year-old male with an acute abscess on the dorsum of the right hand.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical efficacy and safety of different operation sequences (acupuncture followed by cupping vs. cupping followed by acupuncture) for treating lumbar muscle strain with cold and dampness.
results_summary: Both sequences improved pain, disability, and lumbar temperature, but cupping followed by acupuncture showed better pain relief and lower adverse reaction rates. The overall efficacy rates were similar (92.1% vs. 94.6%).
population_specificity: 76 patients with lumbar muscle strain with cold and dampness.
effective_dosage: Flash cupping for 3 min followed by 10 min retention at specific points, once every two days, 3 times weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different pressures and durations of cupping therapy affect muscle blood flow and oxygenation.
results_summary: The study found that cupping therapy at -300 mmHg for 10 minutes significantly increased oxyhemoglobin and deoxy-hemoglobin levels compared to other pressure and duration combinations, indicating improved muscle blood volume and oxygenation.
population_specificity: 18 participants (specific demographics not provided).
effective_dosage: Pressures of -225 and -300 mmHg for durations of 5 and 10 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the risk of disseminated Staphylococcus aureus infection following cupping therapy, emphasizing the need for high hygiene standards.
results_summary: The study reported a rare case of severe infection (including fever, organ injury, and abscess) after wet cupping in an immunocompetent patient, successfully treated with antibiotics. It underscores infection risks despite cupping's general safety reputation.
population_specificity: 33-year-old immunocompetent woman

study_goal: To determine the effects of acupuncture combined with pricking and cupping therapy on the balance of Th1/Th2 cytokines and clinical outcomes in patients with chronic spontaneous urticaria (CSU).
results_summary: The combination therapy significantly improved clinical efficacy, reduced IgE and IL-4 levels, increased IFN-γ levels, and improved symptoms, quality of life, sleep quality, and emotional states compared to traditional therapy, with no significant difference in adverse reactions.
population_specificity: 75 patients with chronic spontaneous urticaria (CSU).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the histologic effects of adding cupping therapy to microneedling, particularly on skin thickness and collagen production.
results_summary: Cupping therapy increased the thickness of the epidermis and dermis when combined with microneedling, but did not significantly affect type I or III collagen immunostaining. A significant increase in type I collagen was only observed in the single-session microneedling group.
population_specificity: Thirty Wistar rats divided into five groups.
effective_dosage: 15-minute cupping therapy sessions added to microneedling, either once or over three sessions at 3-week intervals.
study_duration: Four weeks following the last treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of cupping therapy (Ḥijāma) as a non-pharmacological treatment for pain management in cervical spondylosis, based on Unani medicine literature and published research.
results_summary: The review found that cupping therapy is considered safe and effective for managing pain in cervical spondylosis, as supported by classical Unani texts and research papers. It highlighted cupping therapy as a prominent non-pharmacological regimen for musculoskeletal pain.
population_specificity: Patients with cervical spondylosis, particularly those experiencing neck pain and related symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different pressures and durations of cupping therapy on reducing muscle stiffness in the triceps.
results_summary: The study found that 10-minute cupping at -300 mmHg was more effective at reducing stiffness in the deep layer of the triceps compared to 5-minute cupping. No significant interactions between pressure and duration factors were observed, but the deep layer showed greater sensitivity to cupping therapy.
population_specificity: 12 healthy young people
effective_dosage: Two negative pressures (-225 and -300 mmHg) and two durations (5 and 10 minutes)

study_goal: To compare the clinical effects of pricking-cupping therapy versus acupuncture-cupping therapy on cervical spondylotic radiculopathy (CSR) with qi stagnation and blood stasis, and evaluate trapezius muscle elasticity using ultrasonic shear wave elastography.
results_summary: Pricking-cupping therapy showed greater improvement in trapezius muscle elasticity, pain relief, and cervical function compared to acupuncture-cupping therapy, with a higher total effective rate (91.4% vs. 68.6%). Both therapies significantly reduced Young's modulus values, VAS scores, and NDI scores post-treatment.
population_specificity: 70 patients with CSR of qi stagnation and blood stasis.
effective_dosage: Treatment once every other day, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of moving cupping therapy on chemotherapy-related side effects and quality of life in people with colorectal cancer (CRC).
results_summary: Participants showed significant improvements in quality of life, physical function, fatigue, nausea/vomiting, sleep disturbance, and pain after receiving moving cupping therapy. The study concluded that cupping therapy relieved some chemotherapy-related side effects in CRC patients.
population_specificity: Individuals diagnosed with colorectal cancer experiencing chemotherapy-related side effects.
effective_dosage: 3 times a week for 10 consecutive weeks (average of 25.7 treatments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize Professor ZHANG Jian-bin's clinical experience with moving cupping therapy on the back and its role in diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis evaluation.
results_summary: The study found that moving cupping therapy aids in diagnosing disorders by observing cupping marks, provides targeted treatment, and helps evaluate disease prognosis based on patient feedback over multiple sessions.
population_specificity: Not specified (clinical practice patients)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential effect of Hijama (Cupping Therapy) on oral health by analyzing its impact on saliva flow and pH.
results_summary: The study found that Hijama significantly increased saliva volume and pH immediately after the procedure, with effects maintained for 7 days. The intervention explained 48.8% of the variability in these outcomes, demonstrating large effect sizes.
population_specificity: 41 healthy volunteers (21 in the Hijama group, 20 controls) at a clinic in Saudi Arabia.
study_duration: Immediate effects measured 30 minutes post-procedure; follow-up at 7 days.

study_goal: To determine the effects of pricking and cupping therapy combined with Chinese herbal wet compress on Th1/Th2 balance and substance P concentration in acute-stage herpes zoster patients.
results_summary: The combined therapy significantly improved pain relief, sleep quality, and herpes recovery, while also balancing Th1/Th2 and reducing substance P levels. The treatment group showed superior outcomes compared to control groups.
population_specificity: Patients with acute-stage herpes zoster.
effective_dosage: Not specified (basic treatment + pricking/cupping + herbal compress).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of static cupping therapy on primary dysmenorrhea and related non-specific low back pain.
results_summary: After a two-day static cupping therapy protocol, the patient's pain intensity decreased from 6/10 to 2/10 during activity and from 4/10 to 2/10 at rest. The study highlights the potential benefits of cupping for alleviating menstrual and low back pain.
population_specificity: A 23-year-old female with severe abdominal pain and low back pain during menstruation.
effective_dosage: Two-day supervised static cupping therapy protocol (specific details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dry and wet cupping therapy on low back pain (LBP) in adults by analyzing randomized clinical trials.
results_summary: Wet cupping therapy significantly reduced pain intensity and improved quality of life in LBP patients, while dry cupping showed no significant pain reduction. Both therapies improved quality of life compared to controls, but the study noted high heterogeneity in treatment protocols.
population_specificity: Adults with low back pain (690 patients across 10 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential risks of substandard cupping therapy, specifically its association with subdural hematoma (SDH) due to intracranial pressure reduction (ICPR).
results_summary: The study reported three cases of SDH following substandard cupping therapy, where cups were placed on the occipital-neck junction (ONJ), leading to repeated ICPR and subsequent SDH. The findings suggest that improper cupping techniques can cause severe adverse effects.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent substandard cupping therapy (three reported cases).

study_goal: To evaluate the evidence level of the effect of cupping therapy in managing common musculoskeletal and sports conditions.
results_summary: The evidence for cupping therapy's effectiveness is low to moderate, with moderate evidence for increasing soft tissue flexibility and low to moderate evidence for reducing low back or cervical pain. Adverse events were very low.
population_specificity: Individuals with musculoskeletal and sports-related conditions.
effective_dosage: Not specified (varied by study, including dry and wet cupping).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical usage, application procedures, and perceived effectiveness of cupping therapy among healthcare professionals in the United States.
results_summary: Dry cupping was the most commonly used type (99%), with 75% of respondents employing both static and moving techniques. Cupping was reported as most effective for muscle tightness, myofascial trigger points, and musculoskeletal pain.
population_specificity: 158 healthcare professionals, primarily athletic trainers in secondary school (30%) or collegiate settings (48%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effects of ear acupuncture combined with cupping therapy on chronic back pain compared to ear acupuncture alone.
results_summary: The study found that combining ear acupuncture with cupping therapy significantly improved pain severity, pain relief, and physical disability compared to ear acupuncture alone, with benefits persisting at follow-up.
population_specificity: 198 participants with chronic back pain.
study_duration: Not specified (data collected before first session, after last session, and seven days post-treatment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of dry cupping on pain and functional disability in individuals with persistent nonspecific low back pain compared to a sham treatment.
results_summary: The cupping therapy group showed significantly lower pain (VAS) and functional disability (ODI) post-treatment compared to the sham group, with large effect sizes. While pain improvements persisted at follow-up, functional disability differences did not.
population_specificity: Individuals with persistent nonspecific low back pain.
study_duration: Intervention lasted approximately 2.5 weeks, with a 4-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review and meta-analyze the effects of cupping therapy on obesity, focusing on outcomes like body weight, BMI, and body fat metrics.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, as it describes a planned systematic review and meta-analysis rather than reporting findings.
population_specificity: Obese patients (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: To investigate the effects of wet-cupping therapy (hijama) on autoimmune activity and thyroid hormonal profiles in Hashimoto's disease patients.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in anti-TPO, anti-TG, TSH, prolactin, and ESR levels in the hijama group compared to controls, along with patient-reported clinical improvements and positive ultrasound changes.
population_specificity: Adult females with Hashimoto's disease at an endocrinology clinic in Saudi Arabia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of cupping therapy in the treatment of asthma through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials.
results_summary: The study concluded that cupping therapy is effective and safe for treating asthma, though specific results from the meta-analysis are not detailed in the abstract. The findings were intended for submission to a peer-reviewed journal.
population_specificity: Patients with asthma (chronic airway disease characterized by wheezing, dyspnea, chest tightness, and coughing).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to design an auxiliary isolation device for cupping therapy to prevent cross-infection and simplify disinfection steps.
results_summary: The study found that the device effectively prevents direct contact between the fire cup and the patient's skin, offering safety protection, simplicity, and time efficiency. The device consists of disposable, fire-proof plastic and elastic components.
population_specificity: Not specified (general cupping therapy patients implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immediate and delayed effects of cupping therapy on reducing biceps brachii muscle fatigue induced by exercise.
results_summary: The study found no significant immediate effect of cupping therapy on reducing muscle fatigue, but it demonstrated a significant delayed effect (after 24 hours) in improving recovery compared to sham control, as evidenced by changes in EMG spectral analyses.
population_specificity: Twelve healthy untrained participants.
study_duration: Single session with follow-up at 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of cupping therapy in treating intractable peripheral facial paralysis (IPFP).
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a systematic review and meta-analysis to assess cupping therapy's efficacy and safety for IPFP, but specific results are not yet available as the abstract describes the planned methodology.
population_specificity: Patients with intractable peripheral facial paralysis (IPFP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of cupping therapy for migraine through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Wet cupping showed a higher total effective rate compared to drugs, and dry cupping plus acupuncture was more effective than acupuncture alone, though not statistically significant. Qualitative analysis indicated wet cupping could reduce headache pain and improve quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with migraine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize existing theories on the physiological mechanisms of cupping therapy and review its clinical applications for conditions like cardiovascular diseases, chronic musculoskeletal pain, and arthritis.
results_summary: The study found that cupping therapy may work through multiple mechanisms, including blood circulation promotion, neurological reflexes, pain modulation, and immune responses, with clinical benefits observed for pain and inflammatory conditions.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiovascular diseases, chronic musculoskeletal pain, migraine, and arthritis (based on reviewed studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the current evidence in systematic reviews on cupping therapy for various conditions and create an evidence map to visualize research volume and findings.
results_summary: The study found potential benefits of cupping for conditions like low back pain, ankylosing spondylitis, knee osteoarthritis, neck pain, herpes zoster, migraine, plaque psoriasis, and chronic urticaria, with some systematic reviews demonstrating statistically significant benefits. The evidence map provided a visual overview of cupping research, highlighting areas like musculoskeletal pain and skin diseases.
population_specificity: Patients with various conditions including musculoskeletal pain (low back pain, neck pain, knee osteoarthritis) and skin diseases (plaque psoriasis, chronic urticaria).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness of wet cupping therapy on headache severity and its complications in patients with chronic migraine.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in headache severity from very intense pain (6.66) before therapy to very mild pain (0.72) one month after wet cupping therapy. Reported complications included skin pigmentation (6.9%), scarring (24.1%), and itching (31.0%).
population_specificity: 29 patients diagnosed with migraine (mean age 36.17 years, average migraine duration 11.14 years).
study_duration: Single session with follow-up at 1 hour and one month post-therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dry cupping therapy improves pain intensity, physical function, mobility, quality of life, psychological symptoms, and medication use in individuals with chronic non-specific low back pain.
results_summary: Dry cupping therapy showed negligible effects on pain intensity, physical function, mobility, and other secondary outcomes compared to sham cupping, with no clinically meaningful benefits observed. The study concluded that dry cupping was not superior to sham therapy for any measured outcome.
population_specificity: Ninety participants with chronic non-specific low back pain.
effective_dosage: Once a week for 8 weeks, with cups bilaterally positioned parallel to the L1 to L5 vertebrae.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to propose a model framework for standardizing the safety and quality of care in cupping therapy.
results_summary: The abstract notes that cupping therapy is generally safe but can cause adverse events, most of which are preventable. It emphasizes the need for standardized safety and quality practices.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a case of cupping therapy and briefly review its use in treating various conditions, primarily musculoskeletal pain and dermatoses.
results_summary: The abstract notes that cupping therapy is widely used for musculoskeletal pain and muscular tension, but its mechanisms are not fully understood. Adverse events are most common at the skin level, though efficacy for dermatoses is mentioned.
population_specificity: Not specified (general mention of use for musculoskeletal pain and dermatoses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of cupping therapy as a conservative adjunct option for managing carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).
results_summary: The abstract indicates that cupping therapy has potential therapeutic value for CTS, but the evidence is insufficient to support its inclusion in formal management pathways. High-quality trials with larger participant numbers and better study designs are needed.
population_specificity: Patients with carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effect of three different cupping sizes (35, 40, and 45 mm) on skin blood flow (SBF) responses in healthy participants.
results_summary: All three cupping sizes significantly increased peak SBF, with the 45 mm cup showing the highest increase compared to the 35 mm cup. The 45 mm cup also resulted in longer recovery times and greater total SBF.
population_specificity: 12 healthy participants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of different pressures (-225 mmHg vs. -300 mmHg) and durations (5 min vs. 10 min) of cupping therapy on skin blood flow responses.
results_summary: Higher negative pressure (-300 mmHg) significantly increased peak skin blood flow compared to lower pressure (-225 mmHg), with the largest difference observed between -300 mmHg for 5 min and -225 mmHg for 10 min. Shorter duration (5 min) resulted in larger peak and total skin blood flow compared to longer duration (10 min).
population_specificity: 12 healthy participants
effective_dosage: Pressures of -225 mmHg and -300 mmHg; durations of 5 min and 10 min
study_duration: Four protocols tested on four different days

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical efficacy of rolling needle pricking-cupping (RNP-C) and traditional pricking-cupping (TP-C) versus electroacupuncture (EA) for treating cervical spondylosis of neck type.
results_summary: Both RNP-C and TP-C significantly reduced neck pain (NPQ and VAS scores) compared to EA, with similar efficacy between the two cupping methods. RNP-C caused less acupuncture pain than TP-C, but overall effectiveness rates were comparable (75-79% vs. 63% for EA).
population_specificity: 96 patients with cervical spondylosis of neck type.
effective_dosage: EA: 20 min/session, every 3-5 days (6 sessions total); Cupping: once weekly for 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of using a partially randomized patients' preference (PRPP) trial model to compare acupuncture and cupping therapy for fibromyalgia.
results_summary: The study found no statistical differences in drop-out rates, patient expectations, or satisfaction between cupping therapy and acupuncture groups. The PRPP model was deemed suitable for evaluating non-pharmaceutical therapies.
population_specificity: 126 participants with fibromyalgia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the transdermal enhancement effect of Fu's Cupping Therapy (FCT) on drugs with different molecular weights and compare its efficacy with other penetration enhancers.
results_summary: FCT significantly improved the percutaneous penetration of selected drugs, particularly those with low log(P) values and large molecular weights (ginsenoside Rg1 and notoginsenoside R1), outperforming other enhancers like azone and peppermint oil. The optimal application time for FCT was found to be 10 minutes.
population_specificity: BALB/c-nu mice and Sprague Dawley rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a rare case of cervical artery dissection following cupping therapy and assess its potential risks.
results_summary: The study reported a case of cervical artery dissection after cupping therapy, highlighting its potential for severe side effects. The authors concluded that therapists should be aware of these risks and consider ICA dissection in cases of unexplained neck pain or headache with neurological deficits.
population_specificity: A single case of an individual experiencing cervical artery dissection after cupping therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute effects of myofascial decompression (cupping) and self-myofascial release (foam rolling with heat) on hamstring flexibility and patient-rated outcomes in individuals with hamstring pathology.
results_summary: Both treatments improved hamstring flexibility and patient-rated outcomes, but cupping (MFD) showed a significantly greater perceived benefit in the Global Rating of Change measure compared to foam rolling with heat (SMR).
population_specificity: Seventeen collegiate athletes (13 males, 4 females) with diagnosed hamstring pathology (mild strain, tightness, pain, decreased strength, or flexibility).
effective_dosage: MFD group received 3 minutes of static cupping with six suction cups followed by 20 repetitions of active movement; SMR group received 10 minutes of heat and 150 seconds of foam rolling.
study_duration: Single session (acute effects measured immediately post-intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effect of different cup sizes (45, 40, and 35 mm) in cupping therapy on reducing muscle stiffness, particularly in the triceps.
results_summary: Cupping therapy significantly reduced overall muscle stiffness with 45-mm and 40-mm cups, especially in the deep layer, but not with the 35-mm cup. The superficial layer showed no significant changes across all cup sizes.
population_specificity: 12 healthy participants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate skin blood flow control mechanisms in response to different intensities of cupping therapy using laser Doppler flowmetry and wavelet analysis.
results_summary: Cupping therapy increased skin blood flow, with metabolic and cardiac controls contributing to this effect. The 45-mm cupping protocol showed significantly higher metabolic control responses compared to smaller cup sizes, while cardiac control responses did not differ among protocols.
population_specificity: Twelve healthy participants
effective_dosage: Three cup sizes (35, 40, and 45 mm in diameter) with 300 mm Hg negative pressure

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of cupping therapy at three different pressure levels in relieving fatigue symptoms and improving emotional and sleep conditions in patients with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS).
results_summary: Cupping therapy significantly reduced fatigue symptoms and improved emotional and sleep conditions in CFS patients, with 10 sessions showing superior results compared to 5 sessions. However, no statistical differences were observed between the three pressure groups for secondary outcomes (FAI, SAS, SDS, and PSQI scores).
population_specificity: Patients with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS)
effective_dosage: Cupping pressures of -0.02 MPa, -0.03 MPa, and -0.05 MPa, administered in 10 sessions over 5 weeks (2 sessions per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore curcumin's role and molecular mechanism in improving inflammation-induced osteogenic differentiation disorders in human bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (hBMSCs).
results_summary: Curcumin reduced LPS-induced inflammation in hBMSCs by inhibiting HMGB1 expression, which suppressed the NF-κB pathway and activated the NRF2 pathway, thereby improving osteogenic differentiation. It reversed the decrease in osteogenic markers (Runx2, COL1, OCN, OPN) and restored ALP activity and calcium deposition.
population_specificity: Human bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (hBMSCs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the cytotoxicity, antioxidant, and apoptotic activity of Curcumin nanoparticles on squamous cell carcinoma (HEp-2).
results_summary: The study found that Curcumin nanoparticles exhibited concentration-dependent cytotoxicity, enhanced apoptosis, and induced cell cycle arrest at G2/M and pre-G1 phases. Elevated ROS levels post-treatment indicated significant biochemical changes.
population_specificity: Squamous cell carcinoma (HEp-2) cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether co-administration of PLGA nanoparticles encapsulating curcumin (PLGA-CUR) could enhance CNS drug delivery, reduce neuroinflammation, and mitigate oxidative stress in the context of HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND).
results_summary: The study found that PLGA-CUR nanoparticles improved antioxidant capacity in U1 macrophages, reduced proinflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, TNFα, and IL-18), and preserved neuronal markers (L1CAM, synaptophysin, NeuN, GFAP) in vivo, demonstrating efficacy in targeting CNS reservoirs and mitigating neuroinflammation.
population_specificity: U1 macrophages (in vitro) and Balb/c mice (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a novel nano-composite (cGQDs-PEG-curcumin) in overcoming curcumin's water insolubility and enhancing its photodynamic therapy (PDT) potential for cancer treatment.
results_summary: The nano-composite demonstrated remarkable efficacy in inducing DNA damage after irradiation without ROS production, disrupting cell membrane and nucleolar integrity, and impairing ribosomal synthesis in tumor cells.
population_specificity: In vitro cellular study (specific cell type not mentioned).
effective_dosage: Not specified (irradiation dose: 5 J/cm² of 414 nm light).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of curcumin on CD95 receptor expression in HepG2 liver cancer cells and assess its role in apoptosis.
results_summary: Curcumin treatment significantly increased CD95 expression and enhanced both the quantity and affinity of CD95 binding sites on HepG2 cells, suggesting a potential mechanism for curcumin-induced apoptosis in liver cancer.
population_specificity: HepG2 liver cancer cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy and safety of moving cupping therapy, either alone or in combination with other treatments, for plaque psoriasis.
results_summary: Moving cupping therapy showed significant efficacy in treating plaque psoriasis, reducing inflammation and recurrence rates, with fewer side effects compared to pharmaceutical medications. However, it did not show clear advantages in improving visual analogue scores.
population_specificity: 1164 participants with plaque psoriasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop rapid-acting antidepressants by designing and testing chlorine-containing curcumin analogues, focusing on their anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties.
results_summary: The study found that the curcumin analogue CAK06 exhibited potent antidepressant effects, reducing oxidative stress and inflammation while enhancing synaptic plasticity via the Nrf2-HO-1/BDNF-TrkB pathway. CAK06 outperformed fluoxetine in improving depression-like behaviors after 28 days.
population_specificity: CUMS (chronic unpredictable mild stress) depression model mice and BV2 cell stress models.
study_duration: 14 days for rapid effects, 28 days for pronounced behavioral improvements.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether curcumin enhances the cytotoxic activity of CAR T-cells while reducing pro-inflammatory cytokine production in vitro.
results_summary: Curcumin improved CAR T-cell cytotoxicity against Nalm-6 leukemia cells and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-2, IFN-γ). Network pharmacology and molecular docking suggested curcumin modulates T-cell activation and cytokine regulation pathways.
population_specificity: In vitro study using anti-CD19 CAR T-cells and Nalm-6 B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of prebiotic supplementation combined with dietary counseling on hepatic injury, liver fat, gut microbiota, and metabolic outcomes in patients with NAFLD.
results_summary: The study investigated prebiotic supplementation alongside dietary counseling for weight loss, focusing on improvements in hepatic injury, liver fat, and metabolic parameters, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults with BMI ≥25 and confirmed NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the role of dietary counseling as part of a preventive oral health plan for Sjögren's syndrome patients to improve quality of life and avoid oral complications.
results_summary: The study suggests that dietary counseling, alongside meticulous oral hygiene instructions and chemotherapeutic agents, can help manage oral complications in Sjögren's syndrome patients, though specific efficacy data is not detailed.
population_specificity: Primarily perimenopausal women with Sjögren's syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of dietary counseling in managing serum phosphorus levels in patients with chronic kidney disease, alongside phosphate binder therapies.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that dietary counseling is a pivotal component of managing serum phosphorus levels, though patient adherence remains an issue due to adverse effects and pill burdens. The study also discusses the efficacy of new iron-based phosphate binders but does not provide specific results on dietary counseling alone.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of mind-body medicine (MBM) programs, which include dietary counseling, on cardiac events, mortality, and secondary outcomes like atherosclerosis and blood pressure in patients with coronary heart disease (CHD).
results_summary: MBM programs, including dietary counseling, significantly reduced cardiac events, atherosclerosis, and systolic blood pressure but did not affect overall mortality, cardiac mortality, diastolic blood pressure, LDL cholesterol, or BMI.
population_specificity: Patients with coronary heart disease (CHD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary counseling combined with different exercise regimens on mood, body image, and self-esteem in adolescents with obesity.
results_summary: Dietary counseling, combined with exercise, improved body image and physical self-perceptions across all groups, with resistance and combined training showing greater psychological benefits than aerobic training alone. Psychological improvements were linked to better adherence and reductions in body fat.
population_specificity: Postpubertal adolescents (ages 14-18, 91 males, 213 females) with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and early effects of a lifestyle intervention (including dietary counseling) on body composition, metabolic parameters, and kidney function in obese patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The intervention led to significant reductions in BMI and fat mass, improvements in exercise capacity, insulin sensitivity, and adipokine levels, but no change in kidney function. Quality of life measures also improved.
population_specificity: Obese subjects with chronic kidney disease (median age 57, BMI 43.9).
effective_dosage: 500 kcal reduction in daily caloric intake.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a low-carbohydrate diet versus a low-fat diet on appetite-related hormones and self-reported appetite changes over a year-long period.
results_summary: The study found that a low-fat diet reduced peptide YY more than a low-carbohydrate diet, suggesting better satiety preservation on the latter. No differences were observed in ghrelin levels or self-reported appetite changes between the two diets.
population_specificity: 148 adults with a BMI of 30-45 kg/m², free of diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and chronic kidney disease.
effective_dosage: Low-carbohydrate diet (<40 g/day excluding fiber); low-fat diet (<30% energy from fat, <7% from saturated fat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a low-carbohydrate diet versus a fat-reduced diet on weight gain and nicotine withdrawal in overweight or obese smokers using varenicline.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in weight gain between the low-carbohydrate and fat-reduced diet groups, but nicotine withdrawal symptoms were lower in the fat-reduced group. Smoking abstinence rates did not differ between diets, and dietary counseling did not impair cessation rates compared to previous studies.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese smokers (BMI 25-40 kg/m²) using varenicline to quit smoking.
effective_dosage: Not specified for dietary counseling; varenicline was administered as a 12-week course starting 10 days prior to the target quit date.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of patient-tailored nutritional counseling on body composition, morbidity, and mortality in cachectic cancer patients.
results_summary: Nutrition therapy helped maintain body weight and improved nutritional balance, with the therapy group showing better weight retention and shorter hospital stays. Survival rates were also higher in the nutrition therapy group after two years.
population_specificity: Newly diagnosed, treatment-naive cancer patients with cachexia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if infancy-onset, low saturated fat-oriented dietary counseling influences serum adiponectin levels in adolescents and its association with vascular health markers and cardio-metabolic risk factors.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in adiponectin levels between the intervention and control groups. Low adiponectin was associated with carotid IMT and metabolic syndrome, but dietary counseling did not influence adiponectin levels.
population_specificity: Healthy adolescents (age 15 years)
study_duration: Longitudinal intervention from infancy to adolescence (15 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different exercise regimens combined with dietary counseling on abdominal fat and metabolic markers in obese adolescents.
results_summary: Dietary counseling combined with aerobic, resistance, or combined training reduced abdominal subcutaneous fat (SAT) and improved ApoB/ApoA-1 ratios, with combined training showing the most significant improvements. No significant changes were observed in visceral fat (VAT), ApoA-1, or HSCRP levels.
population_specificity: Post-pubertal adolescents (aged 14-18) with overweight or obesity (BMI ≥85th percentile).
effective_dosage: Maximum daily energy deficit of 250 kcal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary counseling, n-3 PUFA supplementation, or both could affect components of the IL-6 trans-signaling system, which is linked to cardiovascular risk.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of dietary counseling or n-3 PUFA supplementation on circulating levels of sGP130, sIL-6r, or IL-6, suggesting their benefits are independent of the IL-6ts system.
population_specificity: Elderly high-risk men (n=563)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of dietary counseling as a first-line treatment for dyslipidemia in children with advanced CKD and ESRD, particularly in those with multiple CVD risk factors.
results_summary: The study suggests that dietary counseling, as part of therapeutic lifestyle changes, is recommended for children with advanced CKD and multiple CVD risk factors, though the efficacy of pharmacologic treatments like statins is noted but lacks robust randomized trial data.
population_specificity: Children with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) exhibiting dyslipidemia and multiple CVD risk factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Mediterranean-like dietary counseling and omega-3 fatty acid supplementation could reduce serum fractalkine levels and predict cardiovascular disease in elderly men at high risk of coronary artery disease.
results_summary: Fractalkine levels decreased significantly over three years in all groups, but neither dietary counseling nor omega-3 supplementation influenced these changes. Baseline fractalkine levels did not predict cardiovascular events or mortality.
population_specificity: 563 elderly men (aged 64-75 years) at high risk of coronary artery disease.
effective_dosage: 2.4 g/day of omega-3 fatty acids (n-3 PUFA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of dietary counseling, along with oral hygiene, in reducing white spot lesions (WSL) and the dmft index in primary teeth compared to other interventions.
results_summary: Dietary counseling (group 2) led to a 10% reduction in WSL size and a small increase in the dmft index (0.42), showing modest but statistically significant effects compared to the control group. However, it was less effective than fluoride varnish or CPP-ACP applications.
population_specificity: 140 children aged 12-36 months with WSL in anterior maxillary teeth (122 completed the study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (only oral hygiene and dietary counseling described).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an exercise and dietary counseling program could improve body fat, physical function, and quality of life in triple-negative breast cancer survivors, and whether it affected obesity-related biomarkers.
results_summary: The intervention group lost more body fat, improved quality of life, and reduced sedentary time compared to controls, but showed no significant changes in exercise capacity, serum cytokines, or adipokines. BMI was correlated with favorable changes in leptin and adiponectin.
population_specificity: Survivors of triple-negative breast cancer with BMI >25.
effective_dosage: Moderate-intensity aerobic exercise (150 min per week) and diet counseling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of active versus passive educational interventions on improving dietary counseling and other treatment measures for hypertensive patients in primary care.
results_summary: The active educational intervention significantly improved dietary counseling rates (76% vs. 61% in the passive group, p < .01), but patient outcomes did not differ between groups.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients in primary health care in Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early dietary counseling could mitigate the association between familial high lipoprotein(a) concentrations and endothelial dysfunction in children.
results_summary: The study found that familial high Lp(a) concentrations were associated with attenuated endothelial function in control group children, but this association was absent in the intervention group, suggesting dietary counseling may mitigate the effect. Children with high Lp(a) concentrations in the intervention group showed no attenuation in endothelial function.
population_specificity: Seven-month-old children (n = 1062) with familial high lipoprotein(a) concentrations, followed until age 11.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if dietary counseling during pregnancy could increase fish intake and affect serum phospholipid fatty acids, gestational weight gain, and body composition changes.
results_summary: Dietary counseling increased fish intake in the intervention group, and fish intake correlated with higher serum EPA and DHA levels. Meat intake in early pregnancy was associated with increased fat-free mass gain.
population_specificity: Women of normal weight participating in the Pregnancy Obesity Nutrition and Child Health study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if dietary counseling could effectively reduce dental caries in children with ADHD by focusing on home plaque removal and reducing cariogenic food and drink consumption.
results_summary: The study concluded that dietary counseling, along with more frequent recare visits and improved home plaque removal practices, is an effective method for reducing dental caries in children with ADHD, though decreased salivary flow from ADHD medication was not found to be a significant factor.
population_specificity: Children with ADHD

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Enhanced Dietary Counseling (EDC) versus Standard of Care Dietary Counseling (SDC) on BMI trajectory in youth with new-onset type 1 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in BMI Z score changes between EDC and SDC groups, with over 50% of subjects exceeding pre-diagnosis BMI levels after 12 months. EDC improved knowledge of recommended daily energy intake and fruit servings but did not prevent BMI increases.
population_specificity: Youth with new-onset type 1 diabetes (n = 47; aged 8.9 ± 4.2 years).
effective_dosage: EDC included monthly nutritional education and 3-day food records at 6 and 24 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effect of low-saturated fat dietary counseling on arterial distensibility from childhood to early adulthood and assess its association with left ventricular mass.
results_summary: The study found that low-saturated fat dietary counseling was not significantly associated with arterial distensibility. Arterial distensibility decreased with age, more pronounced in boys, and was related to changes in left ventricular mass.
population_specificity: Children and young adults aged 11 to 19 years participating in the STRIP atherosclerosis prevention trial.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a lifestyle intervention, including dietary counseling, on gestational weight gain in pregnant women with normal and above-normal BMI.
results_summary: The intervention reduced gestational weight gain, offspring birth weight, and excessive gestational weight gain in women with normal pre-pregnancy BMI, along with decreased calorie, fat, and cholesterol intake. No significant weight-related changes were observed in women with above-normal BMI, though dietary improvements were noted.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (<20 weeks of pregnancy) without diabetes, stratified by normal (≤24.9 kg/m²) and above-normal pre-pregnancy BMI.
effective_dosage: Dietary counseling was provided twice during pregnancy.
study_duration: Intervention spanned from 20-36 weeks of gestation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary counseling combined with different exercise modalities on body fat percentage in overweight and obese adolescents.
results_summary: Dietary counseling, combined with aerobic, resistance, or combined training, led to reductions in body fat percentage and waist circumference, with resistance training showing the most significant decrease in body fat. Combined training showed greater effects in more adherent participants.
population_specificity: Postpubertal adolescents aged 14-18 years with BMI at or above the 95th percentile or 85th percentile plus additional diabetes/cardiovascular risk factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if automated telephone nutrition support (ATNS) counseling could improve glycemic control in Spanish-speaking patients with diabetes by replicating a successful pilot from Mexico.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in hemoglobin A1c levels (-0.3% in control, -0.1% in intervention, P = .41) or secondary parameters, indicating ATNS did not enhance diabetes control in this population.
population_specificity: Seventy-five Spanish-speaking adult patients with diabetes receiving care at a federally qualified health center in Oakland, California.
effective_dosage: Not specified (automated phone calls prompting dietary input and feedback).
study_duration: 12 weeks (primary outcome measured at 12 weeks post-enrollment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a low-carbohydrate diet versus a low-fat diet on weight loss and cardiovascular risk factors.
results_summary: The low-carbohydrate diet resulted in greater weight loss, reduced fat mass, improved cholesterol ratios, lower triglyceride levels, and higher HDL cholesterol levels compared to the low-fat diet. Both groups received dietary counseling, but the low-carbohydrate approach showed superior outcomes.
population_specificity: 148 men and women without clinical cardiovascular disease or diabetes.
effective_dosage: Low-carbohydrate (<40 g/d) or low-fat (<30% of daily energy intake from total fat, <7% saturated fat).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of dietary counseling in sodium avoidance as part of a broader strategy to improve fluid management in dialysis patients.
results_summary: The study found that dietary counseling should emphasize sodium avoidance to help normalize extracellular fluid volume, which is a primary goal of dialysis care. The consensus highlighted the importance of gradual fluid removal and avoiding intradialytic sodium loading.
population_specificity: Dialysis patients in the United States, specifically those under the care of the largest dialysis providers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of lifestyle intervention (dietary counseling and physical activity) versus meal replacement on glycemic control in prediabetic patients with impaired fasting glucose.
results_summary: Both interventions significantly reduced body weight, BMI, glucose concentrations, insulin levels, and HOMA-IR, with meal replacement showing more pronounced improvements in BMI, insulin, and HOMA-IR. The effects on fasting blood glucose were comparable between the two interventions.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese men and women (age 54 ± 8 y; BMI 32.8 ± 2.89 kg/m²) with prediabetes and impaired fasting glucose.
effective_dosage: Lifestyle group received dietary counseling (fat-restricted low-calorie diet); meal replacement group replaced two daily meals with a low-calorie, high soy-protein drink.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cardiovascular risk reduction effects of a Modified Portfolio Diet (MPD) in medically managed, high-risk patients with type II diabetes post-bypass surgery.
results_summary: The MPD led to a 19% reduction in LDL cholesterol, significant drops in homocysteine levels, improved endothelial function, and increased endothelial progenitor cell numbers, with no significant changes observed in the control group.
population_specificity: 30 patients with type II diabetes, 6 weeks post-bypass surgery.
effective_dosage: Low fat, 8 g/1000 kcal viscous fibres, 17 g/1000 kcal soy protein, and 22 g/1000 kcal almonds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of intensive nutrition counseling on nutritional status, oral intake, morbidity, and quality of life in cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that intensive nutrition counseling improved quality of life (reducing insomnia and nausea) and prevented deterioration in nutritional status (increased well-nourished patients) at 1-month follow-up, though no significant differences were observed in body weight, BMI, or blood parameters between groups during RT.
population_specificity: Cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy (aged 58.0±2.2 years in the intervention group and 62.0±1.8 years in the control group).
effective_dosage: At least three sessions of individualized dietary counseling over the duration of RT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of maternal xylitol consumption versus fluoride varnish on children's salivary mutans streptococci levels, caries activity, and plaque accumulation, with both groups receiving dietary counseling.
results_summary: Maternal xylitol consumption showed non-significant increases in MS levels and no change in caries scores after 24 months, while the fluoride varnish group had significant increases in both. Plaque scores remained unchanged in both groups.
population_specificity: 60 mother-child pairs with high maternal salivary MS levels and children aged 10-36 months.
effective_dosage: Xylitol gum, 1.8 grams (66% xylitol by weight), 3 times/day.
study_duration: 3 months for the intervention, with follow-ups at 6, 12, and 24 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of dietary counseling as part of the treatment for nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), alongside pharmacological agents like vitamin E and pioglitazone.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that dietary counseling, combined with regular exercise, is part of the current therapeutic approach for NASH, though its specific efficacy is not detailed separately from other interventions. The focus is on lifestyle modification as a foundational treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with biopsy-proven nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of dietary counseling on weight loss and energy intake in patients with advanced cancer experiencing different stages of cachexia.
results_summary: Two out of five studies showed less weight loss with dietary counseling, while two others reported a positive effect on energy intake. However, the study concluded there is insufficient evidence to prove dietary counseling significantly improves weight or energy balance in cancer cachexia stages.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced cancer and different stages of cachexia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential benefits of dietary counseling, functional foods, and drugs that interfere with intestinal cholesterol absorption for reducing cardiovascular risk in hemodialysis patients with high cholesterol absorption.
results_summary: The study suggests that hemodialysis patients with high cholesterol absorption may benefit from dietary counseling to reduce cholesterol intake, functional foods containing plant sterols and stanols, and drugs like ezetimibe, bile acid resins, and sevelamer, as statins are less effective in this population.
population_specificity: Patients on maintenance hemodialysis treatment with high cholesterol absorption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if effective dietary counseling methods for sodium restriction could be integrated into primary care models for managing hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that dietary counseling significantly reduced sodium intake (73-93 mmol/day) and blood pressure (-4 to -27 mmHg) in hypertensive patients, but the methods were not feasible for primary care settings due to their complexity (e.g., multiple sessions, prepared food provision, and intensive training).
population_specificity: Adults with untreated hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of dietitian consultations (DC) for orally fed patients and assess the proportion of malnourished patients receiving DC.
results_summary: Dietitians were consulted for 23% of patients, with 44% being well-nourished, 37% mildly/moderately malnourished, and 19% severely malnourished. DC missed 75% of mildly/moderately malnourished and 60% of severely malnourished patients, indicating gaps in nutrition care.
population_specificity: 947 medical and surgical patients in 18 Canadian hospitals who did not receive enteral or parenteral nutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary counseling or oral supplements during chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy in lung cancer patients affect dietary intake, weight, nutritional status, quality of life, functional status, treatment response, or survival.
results_summary: Dietary counseling improved energy and protein intake during chemotherapy but showed no benefit for other outcomes during chemotherapy. There was insufficient evidence regarding its effects during radiotherapy.
population_specificity: Lung cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy and/or radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current recommendations for the nutritional management of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and evaluate the role of dietary counseling in improving glycemic control and cardiovascular risk factors.
results_summary: The study found that dietary counseling, including medical nutrition therapy and lifestyle modifications, can lead to modest weight loss (5%-10% of body weight), which significantly improves glycemic control, lipids, blood pressure, and other cardiovascular risk factors. Combining dietary approaches with pharmacologic agents may further enhance weight loss.
